According to my knowledge,the virtual circuit approach is explained wrong (it makes it look that connection-oriented and circuit swithcing are the same). The physical path between the machines can't be fixed (because IP a connectionless protocol handles it). The connection-oriented protocol helps the communicating process on both maching to feel that a connection is made by the use of acknowledgments and message ordering.

Hello Brandon. Can you then explain what really is the difference between PLAIN Circuit Switching Technique and Virtual Circuit Switching Technique? Both seem very much the same.
​ @pranavnyavanandi9710  brandon is no more a network engineer
@rishabhinc2936  lol

@pranavnyavanandi9710  The difference is this: With "PLAIN Circuit Switching" you have an physical connection between source and destination that is only created for this data transfer (this is the circuit) and the data can take no other path. It also doesn't require inspection of the data that is being transmitted in any way by the intermediaries.  "Virtual Circuit Switching" on the other hand has a different physical set up. All connections exist at the same time, just as with any other form of packet switching, but the data packets belonging to the same message "remember" which path the other ones took and subsequently all take that same path too. Thereby creating a "virtual" circuit. But in contrast to actual circuit switching no physical connections have to be modified in the network.

I am confused about that too. Both seem the same except that in one, the message is split into multiple packets.

I think I got it. In circuit switching, the connection is established as long as the communication is taking place. In virtual circuit, a different circuit is established each time for each message that is to be sent and also, the message is split into packets. So, there is no fixed connection every time, but since every time, a circuit is anyway established a circuit is "virtually" present always. Thus "virtual" circuit switching.

@computernutztamilandenglis9925  thank you for clearing my doubt

Packets  are divided as  datagrams in small small pieces... It will choose different different paths to reach destination.. In destination it will get ordered by its sequence numbers.. Then one question is there why datagram is connectionless? The connectionless specifies the pieces of datagrams will not be connected together while transferring.. Each will choose separate separate paths.. So if it chooses seperate paths by each then no connections between each other so it called connectionless.. NOTE: datagrams works in Internet requires connection for  transfer....hence datagram is sub division of packet...

We have error control in transport layer... It has several techniques... Which are... Parity checker, 2 dimensional parity checker, checksum, cyclic redundency check.. NOTE: it is only for error detection..
For both error detection and correction you can use hamming code
@computernutztamilandenglis9925  I have a doubt ...but all these switching is done in physical layer right ..then how error control in datalink layer detects

@universal4334  actually in sender side it is top down approach and the error detection not required in sender side.... In receiver side it is bottom up approch so the bits (message) in physical layer will be converted into  frames in data layer then frames converted into packets in network layer.. So it will continue further for other layers upto presentation layer... So the data link layer very near to physical layer which contains x-or gates and X-NOR Gates to detect errors.
in message switching the message is broken and transferred  and at each intermediary node the message packet are received and stored and again transferred to next intermediary node.
